column7: mongodb is another open source project. Mlab and compose is free for certain limit. Ec2 is free for an year
https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/
https://www.compose.com/
https://mlab.com/
Or you can create instance on aws and install mongo on aws
You can use mlab or compose  for mongodb
You can use mlab for remo

@atjonathan I have heard of MongoDB before but didn't want to install it on my surface pro so thought about doing it on something like c9, but didn't have enough disk space. Looks like I may have to fork out for that pro license

@spences10, MongoDB is a no-sql database. we seed our challenges there, and if you want local authentication then it will store user details in the db.

MongoDB: https://www.mongodb.com/
Download: https://www.mongodb.com/download-center?jmp=nav#community

Let us kinow if you had any help :)

@HKuz wow, that's an awesome explanation!! Many thanks :confetti_ball:

@Manish-Giri - I was curious about this so just tested some of the node versions (which Chai are based on) on my machine. So `assert.equal` and `assert.strictEqual` won't work when comparing arrays, it's like checking `["a"] == ["a"] // returns false`. Out of the three you mentioned, only `assert.deepEqual` can compare arrays. When I ran it with some test values, it caught those extra null values and threw an error. One downside is that it looks like the order of the items matters - I'm not sure if that would make the tests too strict for that challenge. If you're purely checking for length, there's a Chai `assert.lengthOf(object, length, [message])`option, or you could go low-tech. Since the `diffArray()` function returns an array, use regular `assert()` where the first argument checks that the `.length` on the result of calling their function equals the length it should be. The test would look something like the following : ```js // .lengthOf "assert.lengthOf(diffArray([\"diorite\", \"andesite\", \"grass\", \"dirt\", \"pink wool\", \"dead shrub\"], [\"diorite\", \"andesite\", \"grass\", \"dirt\", \"dead shrub\"]), 1, 'message: [\"diorite\", \"andesite\", \"grass\", \"dirt\", \"pink wool\", \"dead shrub\"], [\"diorite\", \"andesite\", \"grass\", \"dirt\", \"dead shrub\"] should return an array with one item.');" "assert(diffArray([\"diorite\", \"andesite\", \"grass\", \"dirt\", \"pink wool\", \"dead shrub\"], [\"diorite\", \"andesite\", \"grass\", \"dirt\", \"dead shrub\"]).length === 1, 'message: [\"diorite\", \"andesite\", \"grass\", \"dirt\", \"pink wool\", \"dead shrub\"], [\"diorite\", \"andesite\", \"grass\", \"dirt\", \"dead shrub\"] should return an array with one item.');" ``` If others know of a more elegant way to test using the other methods, I'd be interested in hearing that :smile:
there's also `assert.deepEqual(...)`, which I've seen being used across a lot of tests in the code.

ok, so I fell into a solution by accident
because "false" is a value, but yet it gets filtered out, "0" is a value that gets filtered out

filter expects a boolean back from the function, if the value is not boolean it coerces it, so the falsey values (0, null, NaN, "", undefined) get false and are dropped 
all other values are retained
Why?

"undefined"

So the falsey values get converted to false and are filtered out

Currently, using an invalid `scope`, *only public data* is retrieved but not the private email id (*if this was not intentional*).
https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/blob/staging/server/passport-providers.js#L147
https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/blob/staging/server/passport-providers.js#L161

#### :raising_hand: An issue with link and data grabbing from Github
I noticed the url auth url is `https://github.com/login?client_id=2b2a9dcc53df88ddf452&return_to=/login/oauth/authorize?client_id=2b2a9dcc53df88ddf452&redirect_uri=http://www.freecodecamp.com/auth/github/callback&response_type=code&scope=email`

As one can notice `scope=email` at the end which is not a valid scope according to https://developer.github.com/v3/oauth/#scopes
If it is meant to retrieve *only the public data* of a user, `scope` is not required to be given.
Or if it is meant to retrieve *both public data and private email id*, then `scope` should be set to `user:email`.

I've been following these instructions in `CONTRIBUTing.md`:
```
##### Method 1: Editing via your Local Fork _(Recommended)_

This is the recommended method. Read about [How to Setup and Maintain a Local
Instance of Free Code Camp](#maintaining-your-fork).

1.  Perform the maintenance step of rebasing `staging`.
2.  Ensure you are on the `staging` branch using `git status`:

bash
$ git status
On branch staging
Your branch is up-to-date with 'origin/staging'.

nothing to commit, working directory clean


1.  If you are not on staging or your working directory is not clean, resolve
    any outstanding files/commits and checkout staging `git checkout staging`

2.  Create a branch off of `staging` with git: `git checkout -B
    branch/name-here` **Note:** Branch naming is important. Use a name like
    `fix/short-fix-description` or `feature/short-feature-description`. Review
     the [Contribution Guidelines](#contribution-guidelines) for more detail.

3.  Edit your file(s) locally with the editor of your choice

4.  Check your `git status` to see unstaged files.

5.  Add your edited files: `git add path/to/filename.ext` You can also do: `git
    add .` to add all unstaged files. Take care, though, because you can
    accidentally add files you don't want added. Review your `git status` first.

6.  Commit your edits: `git commit -m "Brief Description of Commit"`

7.  Squash your commits, if there are more than one.

8.  Push your commits to your GitHub Fork: `git push -u origin branch/name-here`

9.  Go to [Common Steps](#common-steps)
```

Hi @chiptus! Nice work on fixing it. First of all, the issue number in your current PR has some characters switched around :smile: Here's how I believe the second PR should be created (disclaimer: I've never created a PR to the backup/master branch before):
```
git checkout backup/master
git checkout -b fix/new-branch-name-here
git cherry-pick 78a1f9f
git push origin fix/new-branch-name-here
```
The third command (cherry-pick) should copy the commit with the hash of `78a1f9f` over to the new branch.
You can then proceed making the Pull Request as usual, making sure to switch the target branch to backup/master. It's probably also a good idea to mention in the PR description what the other PR is and that you were asked in the issue to make this changes to both branches.

The order will be unique to each person, but will always include a combination of the two for best results. Personally, I needed formal understanding the surpassed FCC before I began completing projects. Here is how I learned: YouTube, Documentation, FCC Forum; in that order.
The solution is beginning with classwork where you gain a formal understanding of the language, followed up by immersing yourself in the language, *or* vice versa.

@jesterfrenz I agree with @systimotic on this. Think about this as a comparison. When learning a foreign language what is the best method? Will you learn by taking a formal course, but never immersing yourself in the subject? Yes, this will yield excellent understanding of the language, but will lack practice using the language. Will you learn by simply immersing yourself in a foreign country and learning the language naturally? Yes, this will yield excellent everyday use of the language, but you will lack understanding of the language itself.   What is the solution?

@/all 
# Update on Testable Projects

One major part of our curriculum expansion where we still need help  is with our move to fully testable projects, with a large suite of tests that runs against each project to confirm that campers have met user stories. This will make building projects a more incremental, less ambiguous process. And campers will still have plenty of room to add their own personal style.

Already under development:
- **5 Front End Libraries Projects**: Partially built thanks to @no-stack-dub-sack and @Weezlo. Check out the new [example calculator project with its 15 built-in tests](http://codepen.io/no_stack_dub_sack/pen/amaAzq)
- **5 Responsive Web Design Projects**: @no-stack-dub-sack and @Weezlo are also working on these.
- **5 API and Microservice Projects**: @em-ant and @greenheart have already built these.

Help wanted:
- **5 Data Visualization Projects**: We want to design 5 new data visualization projects from scratch with agile user stories. We're looking for contributors who can help build basic example apps and their test suites (like those @no-stack-dub-sack and @Weezlo have built).
  Here are the new projects: 
  - Mapping Data on a Globe: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumExpansion/issues/66
  - Heatmap: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumExpansion/issues/64
  - Scatterplot: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumExpansion/issues/63
  - Bar chart: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumExpansion/issues/62
  - Force Directed Graph: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumExpansion/issues/65


- **5 Quality Assurance and Information Security Projects**: These were previously called the "Dynamic Web App Challenges" We've designed some agile user stories for these, but haven't built example apps or written tests for them yet. We will only test the API endpoints - not the views. So these will be similar to the API and Microservice projects. We need two volunteers to collaborate on these.
  Here are the new projects: 
  - Metric-Imperial Converter: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumExpansion/issues/75
  - Twitter Clone: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumExpansion/issues/76
  - Stock Price Checker: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumExpansion/issues/77
  - Book Trading App: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumExpansion/issues/78
  - Anonymous Voting App: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumExpansion/issues/79

Here's something from the new moderation guide I'd like to talk about (from the PR requirements):
> 1. It must reference at least one open issue, and the body should also include closes #XXXXX for each issue number it addresses

I have previously talked about this with Quincy in direct messages. Here are the pros and cons from my point of view:
#### Pros
We get a lot of PRs that change functionality in ways we don't want, things like adding buttons to the UI. Discussing the proposed changes in an issue beforehand can save a lot of QA time, and a lot of time for the person making the PR. As PRs that make changes to the functionality or UI have to be reviewed by Berkely and Quincy, they lose a lot of time to PRs like this.

#### Cons
I'm afraid that making this a requirement will cause a lot of 'ghost' issues to be created. People will create an issue for the sole purpose of being able to submit a PR.
I myself have made multiple PRs in the past where I believe it wouldn't make sense to have opened an issue. An example is both of my PRs related to https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/issues/10885. Neither of these PRs directly solved an open issue, but they did solve an existing problem that had been worked around in other ways. If I would've had to open issues for these PRs, the PRs would be merged before anyone even got a chance to look at the issues.  
  
Here's an example that's a bit in-between: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/pull/11065. One could say this PR was unnecessary. It doesn't solve a problem, though I like to think it prevented a problem from happening in the future. If I would've had to open an issue for this, I probably wouldn't have made the PR, because the time spent would not be worth the change made.

I'd like to propose the following: any PR that makes a change to the functionality or the UI should be discussed in an issue first. If a PR that makes a change is opened without discussion beforehand, we thank them for there contribution and ask them to open an issue to discuss this. The PR will be blocked, not closed. Even if we don't want a proposed change, I think we should make an effort not to discourage new contributors who want to help out.

Regardless of what we end up going with, the CONTRIBUTING.md and Pull Request template should be updated to make this requirement very clear.

I'd love to hear what you think about this.

@KonSal Oh, and I guess one trick/resource I've found to be helpful with writing these is to first get the regex working using a site like [Regex 101](https://regex101.com/#javascript), then paste it into the JSON and add all the escape characters.

Okay - the regex makes sense - you could use a non-capturing group for the www. part if you don't need to use the group, but that's not a critical change. It would be (?:www\\.) instead of (www\\.) 
And the double-backslashes are right (nice job!) - I'm assuming that first character before http was supposed to be the forward slash to start the expression?

And this is my take, (which I guess is utterly wrong) to convert it to JSON format:
```
\http:\\/\\/(www\\.)?example\\.com/ig
```

@HKuz Great, thanks :)

@KonSal I don't know of any resources, but have written/converted some assert tests that use regexp in a bunch of challenges. Also, there is an issue with how the lessons are taught, I think that there is a fundamental bit of understanding missing from the curriculum as a whole.
There really isn't a lesson that directly addresses how to utilize parameters.

I wrote this up to help people work out some of the issues with several lessons. (Mostly, Word Blanks)
---
Parameters are values that get passed into your function from the function call. 
You can use parameters like variables.
Example:
```js
function hello(name) {
     return "Hello " + name + ", How is your day?";
}
hello("Joseph"); // "Hello Joseph, How is your day?"
hello("Sally"); // "Hello Sally, How is your day?"
```
You can use the `name` parameter just like a variable inside of your function.

Hopefully, something like this could be adapted to a lesson when FCC is getting a little further along in understanding Functions and how to use Functions within JavaScript.

@andmckvr13 I'm still new with react as well. From what I see:
- challenges retrieved via AJAX (from database) when redux is created
- it will create `store` containing `states` which will be converted into `props` to the react app
- component that responsible to displaying challenges is `common/app/routes/challenges/components/Show.jsx`
- later `Show.jsx` will choose which component that should be loaded as it will use different component for different challenges
- type of challenges (can be seen in Show.jsx):
    * step -> will load `common/app/routes/challenges/components/step/Step.jsx`
    * classic -> will load `common/app/routes/challenges/components/classic/Classic.jsx`
    * etc
- document title is updated by calling action redux action `updateTitle()`
- so if we look at `Show.jsx`, there are some calls to `this.props.updateTitle()`
- the document title will eventually updated by `client/sagas/title-saga.js` -> not sure how redux-epic works

@tadake I would do `HEAD~5` first to get remove the 5 commits that aren't yours, then you can do `git reset --soft HEAD~5 && git commit` to squash your remaining commits (the commits you actually made).
@tadake doing `HEAD~9` will remove nine commits, which is what I don't think you want to do. Right now, it looks like you have a total of 10 commits, but only the first 5 commits is what you want.

@/all I hope your weekend is going well. Quick announcement:

Soon, campers will be able to build all front end projects right on FreeCodeCamp.com (no need for CodePen). We will also use automated tests to check whether campers have completed all of the agile user stories (and code review will become optional). 

This means we need to create user stories that can be tested. And we should err on the side of having lots of tests (I'm thinking ~10 tests per project).

I've created an issue for each of the non-backend projects that will be in our expanded curriculum. Note that we're retiring a few and introducing a few easy web design projects as well. 

Also note that we've already made significant progress overhauling the back end projects to use automatic tests, and we don't currently need help with those. 

Who's interested in helping us redesign some of these projects? Dive in and start commenting on these new issues: https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/CurriculumExpansion/issues

`function largestOfFour(arr) { return arr.map(function (x) { return Math.max.apply(null, x); }); }`

dat ES6 tho
`const largestOfFour = arr => arr.map(x => Math.max(...x));`
@luishendrix92 I know.
You can just use a .map and for each sub-array, perform a Math.max.apply to it and return such value so that the mapped array becomes the requested thing

@revisualize I still stand by my argument against adding varying sizes. Both code examples you've posted aren't incorrect. They both complete the task at hand.

There are plenty other algorithm challenges to test scalability and cleverness. Especially the prime number challenge. Make your code inefficient enough and your code won't finish on FreeCodeCamp.
And of course the methods could be chained and it would just be 5 lines of code.

@revisualize the instructions point out that they use 4 arrays for simplicity

> For simplicity, the provided array will contain exactly 4 sub-arrays.

@revisualize I agree that it is important to think about scalability of your code. However, this challenge is in the basic JavaScript algorithms section. So I don't think it is appropriate for the audience to think about scalability yet at that point, given the typical coders going through the curriculum.
@erictleung Currently, because all the texts have 4 arrays. You can bruteforce the response.

@iddaramola there's no `index.html` file in the traditional sense. The page is rendered with JavaScript and has Jade as a preprocessor. [This](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/blob/549cfc305f75d8c6036a3cde65c47b518607b18c/server/views/home.jade) is the home page if that is what you're looking for.
@erictleung That would force learning how to write a loop and it would force users to think about making their code scale-able.

I'm not an expert on git, but the commands I use to sync my repo is:
```git pull --rebase upstream staging``` to pull the latest updates to my local repo, and
```git push origin staging``` to push those updates to my remote repo on github
If you don't have the latest updates it will say something like "This branch is X commits behind FreeCodeCamp:staging."
When you go to your FCC fork on github, if you have the latest updates it will say "This branch is even with FreeCodeCamp:staging." Like here: https://github.com/jhuynh85/FreeCodeCamp

# Welcome to our Contributors room!

Here you can discuss contributing to our community's open source projects, curriculum, Medium publication, YouTube channel, designing assets, throwing events, and other ways of making Free Code Camp better.

If you are interested in helping improve Free Code Camp in some way, you are in the right place!
